I've noticed a fair number of tsuba have forging/folding
flaws between the hitsu ana and nakago ana. I assume this
is indicative of an "S" type fold, katchushi style. Question-
since many of the old tosho and katchushi styles were re-done
in the revival period, ca 1850, were the plates made in the
old style also or just "factory" plates. Jim's article on
tsuba plates leads me to the revival plates were not likely
made like the old ones. Just wondering.

Thanks
Rich S
